text: >> Let me introduce our two distinguished speakers. So first is Martin Fischer who is
the Kumagai Professor at Stanford School of Engineering and a senior fellow at the Precourt Institute for Energy.
Professor Fischer's research goals are to improve the productivity of project teams involved in designing,
building, and operating facilities, and to enhance the sustainability of the built environment. I'm sure many of you are already familiar with his work.
He develops a theoretical foundations and applications for Virtual Design and Construction, and he's also quite the educator on VDC,
and I think we'll talk a little bit more about that at the end, but he's developed several workshops and courses that instruct people on VDC.
Joining him is Danielle Dy Buncio, the co-founder and CEO of VIATechnik,
a Virtual Design and Construction consulting and implementation firm, transforming the real estate and construction industry by
spearheading the advancement building information modeling, VDC, virtual reality, augmented reality, and artificial intelligence.
She was awarded Building Design and Constructions 40 under 40 in 2018 and ENR Top Young Professionals [inaudible].
It's an our honor to have both of them here today to talk about VDC and a little bit more about Virtual Design and Construction,
and how it can help you take your projects to the next level in terms of efficiency. So with that, I'm going to hand the presentation over to both of them. Martin.
>> Good morning. Thank you, Pax. Good morning, afternoon, evening from my home here in Menlo Park.
I'm Martin Fischer from Stanford, and together with my co-presenter, Danielle Dy Buncio.
I'm very happy to welcome you to this introduction to VDC, Virtual Design and Construction. We'll explain why professionals, projects,
and companies use VDC as the project management approach or framework, and what VDC is,
and we will showcase how projects have benefited from the application of VDC. Before we jump into these topics,
we'll say a few more words about ourselves so that you know where we are coming from.
I grew up in Switzerland, as you may detect by my accent. You see here the house I grew up in and in the left picture of my father.
made me the co-worker, my father is the one in the right. I grew up on construction. As we were building our house,
like every other client, we had more wishes than we had budget, and so the children had to help,
my sister and I had to help build the house on the weekends. So I was one Saturday working on the top floor,
my father gave me a task. I finished it and then I said, "Hey, dad, I'm done come take a look."
He looked at it and said, "Okay. Yeah, you did an okay job, but you would have done a better job if you
had use the particular tool." I said, "I know." Then he said, "Look, why did you not use the tool?"
"Well, the tool was in the basement and I would have had to go get it and come back up two floors."
That was a little much for an 11 year old boy. To do so, I just muddled through.
So to that, this is what I heard from my father. He said, "You are an idiot if you're not using the best tool possible."
This has really stuck with me so I've only to share this little story, so now you know where I'm coming from,
where I grew up in that sense, but also where I'm coming from in my mind, because I'm always looking at the work we do as engineers, managers, designers,
architects, and so on as AC professionals and think about, are we really using the best tools? Because when we have better tools,
we can achieve better things. I'll let Danielle say a few more words about herself.
>> Thanks, Martin. I really love that story. So a little bit about myself. I grew up in the construction industry.
My parents started a infrastructure construction company when I was about three years old. So it's an industry that's very near and dear to my heart.
But I couldn't help but feeling that as time went on, so much technology was hitting the world and our lives were changing,
but a lot of construction was staying stagnant. So about eight years ago, I founded a company called VIATechnik,
which focuses on bringing that sort of technology, VDC and related tools to the industry.
We work with companies in three different ways. One is in an advisory capacity, so really understanding "so what's
your corporate strategy and how does your digital strategy align to that?, " also things about maintaining implementation,
so actually implementing VDC and then through education. So I'm very excited to be here today.
>> Thank you very much for joining us, and I think, in this sense of reality.
So why do professionals around the world use VDC?
Surely, they want to create high-performing buildings more often, bring new technologies into their practice in a systematic way and consistent way,
and achieve their corporate aspirations, and also avoid rework.
So very quickly to illustrate those. We see in remarkable projects around the world for many different reasons,
depends on the aspirations of a client. For example, the Tesla Gigafactory was built,
designed and built incredibly fast and actually offers a lot of flexibility in its layout.
The Bullitt Center in Seattle, amazing environmental performance, those being [inaudible] positive,
energy positive. Building at the lower right became very fast, affordable,
but also became, because of that, sustainable. But because of that became the highest money-making real estate deal in Arizona, or in Switzerland,
the longest tunnel ever built. So there's many criteria that we can apply to define what is high performance.
We see some very high-performing buildings, but we also know that too often we have buildings that don't perform quite as highly as they should.
What we found with VDC, you have a better chance of creating a high-performing building.
We are bombarded every day with new technologies around mobile, Cloud,
I mentioned a little control, machine learning, AI, Internet of Things, 3D printing,
virtual reality and so on. Many technologies, everyone by themselves already a big deal,
but in fact, they're all happening right now. What we've seen is that you can bring
these technologies into your practice in a much more focused, strategic way, when you work with a framework like VDC.
I was browsing across a number of websites of companies around the world, and basically,
these are the kinds of statements you read and look for. The first opening statement presents the company.
Work with all the parties involved, achieve common goals. We rethink design and construction, improve performance, focus on the success of clients,  and so on.
I'm sure you've seen these aspirations as well, which are, of course, fantastic. But again, how are we going to
make sure that every project achieves these kinds of aspirations? Again, we have found that VDC is really a way to do so.
Finally, we see still too many problems on site that should not happen that require rework that are base resources,
like this example here, again, from my home country, obviously something has to give, you cannot put the duct through that hole while the electric tray is in front of it.
So these are really the reasons we've seen why companies are moving towards VDC.
So let me introduce VDC in a nutshell, so you've an idea of what it is. In my mind, this is really how you would logically manage projects in 2020.
But of course, it's not always that easy to do the thing that's logical. But let me explain what VDC is.
So of course, to have a great project, you would bring the right people together at the same time,
so that you have the knowledge available you need for the input and the project, for the decision-making, so that those decisions stick.
You move forward in a concerted way and don't have to come back because some ideas show up too late.
So you bring the right people together. But of course, in 2020, there's only so much we can do without digital tools,
so you give them the best tools possible because you have a great team so you should equip the team with great tools.
In particular, tools that are really important is one that focuses on what the client--our clients--are buying.
If you are working for the owner, that also means the clients are the users of the building, for example.
So well, they are buying a building, a road, a couple physical structures from us.
So we need a tool that puts what we design, build,
operate into the computer in digital form so we can share the information about it,
we can see it, we all see the same thing. So a tool like BIM is particularly important given the value that we create for our clients.
But the best people, the best tools together don't achieve much if you don't put them in a good workflow.
So if you don't align, for example, the delivery of design with the architects and construction,
then the project will not be successful. So here you see from a hospital project in San Francisco,
the left diamond shows how far the architects are going to take the design. The right triangle or diamond shows where the builders thought they would pick it up.
Obviously, there was a gap. They were both working with BIM, but there was a gap, and so they figured that out early enough and co-created
the workflow that allowed them to be successful and not point fingers at each other.
So about the best people, the best tools, the best workflows will not achieve
anything meaningful if you're not focused on the right things. So we have to establish and track client and project objectives.
So this is VDC. Bringing people together, we call it integrated concurrent engineering.
Very right key that you bring the people together concurrently and solve problems together.
We give them tools like building information models. We put them in the right management approach,
project production management, we call it. Focus on the production of the project,
and together with these methods of managing people, technology, and process, we achieve what we've found in greater projects and client objectives.
But they are defined in quantifiable, measurable ways. So this is VDC as a whole and VDC in a nutshell.
We'll illustrate the application as we go forward. We showed this typically as a framework like this,
where you have the client objectives that give rise to the project objectives.
Then that allows you to figure out who are the people we need to have on the project,
what tools do they need, and what's the right workflow process so that they can achieve those objectives?
So you can think of VDC in this way. Who should work together? What tool should they use? [NOISE] Sorry here.
How should they work, and what should they achieve? Or you can approach it in this way.
You could say why does the project exist? What does the client really need this building structure for?
What does the project team therefore need to achieve? So the objectives and how
is the project team going to achieve these results? These are the VDC capabilities that need to be brought into an organization.
You can read quite many case studies of the application of VDC in a book.
I had the pleasure of coauthoring with three petitioners called Integrating Project Delivery.
In the book, we build on many successful examples from around the world.
We create the high-performing building as the focus of what we need to achieve and for that we need to define it.
We call that measurable value. You saw examples of that definition at the beginning of the slide deck.
The key role, of course, is to envision early on in
the project the performance you could have with different kinds of designs. For that, we need an integrated set of information about
the project that supports visualizations, simulations, analysis, optimizations, so that we can see what is really achievable.
We need to, of course, orchestrate the people, the organization, and the processes so that we create a building that is indeed high-performing.
Typically, that building or that structure, and when I say building, I really mean it very broadly,
anything that we build in the world. Typically, what we found that a high-performing building has integrated systems.
We have technical systems that are necessary for the building that really support each other and work synergistically.
But those don't just happen by themselves. For that really, we need to bring the organization, the process and information together in an integrated and concentrated way.
So this allows us to connect the three very common acronyms: IPD,
VDC, BIM that we see across the industry. Because we have basically a strategy of integration to create
high-performing buildings supported by a tool like BIM. If you looked over the top right,
the methods that are used to execute this strategy, we see actually VDC.
We see the tools that are used. We see the collaboration. We call it I sessions.
We see production management and we see the objectives. So these are the VDC capabilities and
then we also have alignment capabilities that are also critical. So I wanted to very quickly position VDC also in the context of other common acronyms.
So VDC is not BIM, it's not IPD. VDC is the method to execute the IPD strategy,
integrated project delivery strategy. BIM is a critical part of VDC,
but it's not the same as VDC. So very quickly, I want to take you through a personal journey of how
did I arrive to be passionate about VDC?
Here's one of the first projects I worked on, the Jamestown Verrazzano Bridge in Rhode Island.
We had to redesign it so it was buildable and I had two reflections.
One is, why did the designer and the builder not work together from the beginning for such a complex project?
Why was it such a struggle everyday to find the right information? This really got me to researching BIM and then I was in a way validated.
I felt validated with that direction when I read about the Barcelona project from Frank Gehry,
the Golden Fish, where in 1992, because of the time pressures of having the sculpture ready for the Olympics,
the structure was built directly from the BIM. There was an architect on site with a computer with 3D
model directly feeding the information to the workers so that they could install it rapidly.
So I thought, okay, this is the kind of vision I also believe in construction. Tools started to mature.
We were able to do our first 3D and 4D model for the renovation of the hospital right here in San Mateo in 1993.
We saw the value of BIM to bring diverse project team together and focus it on important issues.
Over time, people realized they will be more effective when they work together side-by-side from different disciplines.
Here you see the first big room used by DPR Construction and its subcontractors on
a medical office building here in Mountain View. That was around 2003, 2004.
On that project, they really brought many aspects of
VDC together because they also rethought the process to leverage the collaboration of the team,
and to leverage the tools for project success. The key thing here is in a typical sequential flow of work is
this double-headed arrow where the design team and the building team together created a buildable,
functional, operable, usable design that requires iteration around the value the client was seeking and for that BIM
and this revised process and the collaboration were absolutely critical. So the result of that project was that it was built
nine percent cheaper and six months faster than comparable buildings. There were many of these types of projects going on around us here.
So we started to see in the early 2000s the value of bringing all of the VDC elements together.
You see again, the VDC framework here illustrated with these experiences over time.
So let us now hopefully, offer a sense of now why companies and professionals use VDC and what VDC is.
Let us further illustrate that with a few case studies from around the world. So as we were defining VDC at our resource center CIFE at Stanford,
we saw that one of our collaborators, SPS,
Strategic Project Solutions, was working with the British Airport Authority on the extension of the Heathrow Express to Terminal 5.
That really is, to my knowledge, the first documented example of the application of VDC.
We didn't call it VDC at the time, but I think it's still a good case study to show where VDC came
from and to show how all the elements work together. On that project, which was quite a massive infrastructural project,
they had a key challenge that they only had three days of lay-down space available for materials on site.
But they had a rebar detailing and fabrication process that had a variability of plus-minus two weeks over six weeks.
So it could take four weeks, it could take eight weeks. So you can see that disconnect here; you have four week variability,
but you only have space for three days worth of materials. They said, "This is not going to work. This is going to create a disaster.
We may not finish the project on time." This was the largest concrete project in Europe at the time,
so this was a big deal. So they said, "Okay, we have to fix it." So how did they approach it?
They said, "Well, we have the range and we have the rebar production process." That's good.
That's a nice idea. What does this actually mean? This means that we have to be able to reduce the lead time from
six weeks to one week because that's where the site can much more reliably signal when rebar is needed.
We need to basically cut out the variability, and we need to reduce the cycle time for
installation so it becomes more predictable from two weeks to two days. So here, you see key parts of how we think about VDC and how we bring VDC onto projects.
You see a focus on the actions, decisions, we call them control the factors that you can take on
your projects and the objective with met quantified targets that you want to achieve to
make this action meaningful and to connect it to what you want to do. Because you can see how if you meet these objectives,
you have a better chance of finishing the project on time, which was, of course, imperative.
So another strategy they had, design the rebar for pre-assembly.
Their specific target was that they wanted to have 75 percent of rebar preassembled, which 15, 17, 18,
years ago, was really quite aggressive, that they wanted to use pull planning for rebar detailing and fabrication,
so they would have just in time delivery and not exceed the three day lay-down space,
and that they wanted to collaboratively detail the rebar in weekly digital build sessions,
so that they could all agree, yes, this is buildable rebar.
So to illustrate that here, the before and after look at the process of engineering, absolutely critical part.
The attention to process, project production management. Then the design for pre-assembly,
a fully detailed rebar in BIM, now very common, at the time much less common.
First time I saw this on a project used at large-scale, and then the pull process so that the site could signal to the engineers, "Okay.
We need this rebar next week, now detail it and make it over the course of the week."
Here, maybe the central piece of the whole strategy. This weekly digital build session where basically everybody that had a say in,
"Yes, this is the right rebar," the cost estimator, the project manager, site foreman,
fabricator and so on, structural engineer, work together in a room and said, "Yes, this works.
We are signing off." You can see how much time you can cut out of a project schedule, how much back and forth you can cut out if you can bring the people
together with good tools in the right process. Put that back into the VDC framework.
We saw here how the combination of defining the challenge, the objective,
and then in measurable ways led to the targeted re-engineering of the process.
The execution was only possible by having these weekly digital build sessions that were supported by a very detailed BIM.
If you take one of those pieces out, you don't have a successful project.
That's what we have for VDC time and again and that's really something that is critical when you use VDC is to not
stop at just using BIM or not stop at just using a lean with maybe a little bit of BIM or not just stopping at
collaboration to really bring all of these work methods
together and to be very deliberate about what objectives you're trying to achieve.
So I'll turn it over to Danielle to share a couple of case studies from her experience.
>> Perfect. Thanks, Martin.
I'm going to share three examples for you today. I think there's a little bit of an echo.
Maybe somebody else put on mute. So I'm going to share three examples for you today. I chose these examples because VDC was used
to address a very specific challenge or project goal. I'm hoping that by going through these three examples pretty quickly,
you'll be able to imagine how VDC can be used on your project. So I'd like to start up with projects where a large co-working office developer
approached us with a specific goal of how they could build projects faster. It was interesting how this project came about.
We had run a VDC workflow with one of our general contractor clients on one of their co-working projects.
This developer has very highly liquidated damages if the project is late, but they also have a bonus if the project is finished early.
So through that VDC workflow with the general contractor, we were able to help them achieve that bonus.
So the owner came to us and said, ''Hey, if this project could've been built that fast,
that should've been the project schedule from the beginning. How can you help us build all of our projects faster?''
So we said, "We think we can do that by utilizing 4D BIM in a well-run VDC framework."
I think one important thing to note about this developer is that they only start leases on the first of the month.
So a two-day delay really turns into a one-month delay,
which means that there is both construction cost implications and then also a loss of revenue.
So what we did was we created a 4D BIM by utilizing
the design BIM and then taking the original general contractor's construction schedule.
We used pull planning methodology to get information from the trade contractors to understand what are their productivities?
What is their test sequencing? What durations do we need to assume?
Then we ran through this with a very specific goal of cutting the schedule by 20 percent.
What was interesting here is we were able to achieve that, but we did not change any duration and we didn't change any productivity rates.
It would be very easy to say, ''Hey, wall framing is on the critical path, it's 10 days.
Let's do it in five days and we'll take five days from your construction schedule.'' We kept all the productivity durations as a given,
we only thought about re-sequencing work. So we were able to say things like, ''Hey,
there's a lot of work happening in zone A, nothing's happening in zone C. Can we get a crew out there?"
Or we have lighting install following duct work install with this much of a lag.
Because we have the schedule in this very visual collaborative format, we can see that there's space to shorten that lag.
So can we do that? I tried to map this project using
the VDC framework so that you can see really how it all came together. So as I said there was this project's objective of maximizing lease revenue,
could we get one extra month of revenue, and reducing schedule duration by 20 percent. But what's really important to note here is how that
really rolls up into client objectives, where you can then apply that schedule-saving methodology
from this project across the global portfolio. I think this is an important point because it
shows that we're able to close the feedback loop. What we've learned here with one VDC workflow on one project,
we can scale across multiple projects and really take advantage of that learning. The 4D BIM was obviously
that essential tool that was used for both visualization and schedule optimization,
but it was really by putting it together with ICE sessions so that we could have
real-time decision making for how to re-sequence work and putting it together with that pull planning methodology.
So as Martin says, ''It's really more than the BIM, it's how it comes together with both the people and the process side.''
The next example I'd like to share is for a wastewater treatment plant and it's a large-scale project,
where the challenge here is specifically to eliminate rework during construction.
It's been a problem on past projects. You can see just by the density and complexity in the scale of the building, this is a challenge.
It's a challenge they've faced before and it's a challenge that resulted in both cost schedule overruns or cost overruns and schedule delays.
So we built a VDC workflow that specifically targeted two goals.
First, eliminate clashes between systems virtually before it happened in the field and second,
enable prefabrication of certain systems so that work on site was reduced.
If work on site could be reduced, that rework could be eliminated.
So when thinking through the BIM execution plan, the level of development of the BIM was aligned to these two goals,
and so the majority of the model was LOD 350. But for certain strategic items that were going to be prefabricated,
the LOD was 400. Architectural and structural elements,
depending on the importance in the interface with those strategic MEPF systems,
was either LOD 300 or 350. The entire team realized the importance of
the clash detection and issue management in achieving that rework reduction goal. So a very detailed approach was used here.
For every issue, six attributes were tracked. So please note that not all issues were geometric clashes necessarily.
Issues could be identified related to constructability, model fidelity, order of operations,
that construction sequencing, for example. Then these six attributes were analyzed by our team as well as
the general contractor's estimating team to determine the impacts that they had on the project; mainly the avoidance of man hours,
labor costs, or material cost. The status, the open date,
the close date that I note here are actually incredibly interesting because it helps us from a process perspective and enables us to understand the real-time status of issue.
This slide shows how that data was visualized. I realize it's probably quite hard to see, so I'll walk through it quickly.
But here in table 1, issue type mix, you see that the majority of clashes are in a light blue color which means they're trade coordination issues.
As a counter example, varied levels in yellow which uncovers true design issues or errors.
So we can see that these issues really can be solved through good construction phase VDC workflows.
Table 2 helps us prioritize the issues. We can see that about a quarter of the issues are high priority or critical.
That's where we should focus our time to have the biggest impact on a project. Table 3 shows which trades are conflicting with each other.
The largest amount of clashes are between two trades, process piping and electrical. So we could see there that we would benefit from ICE session breakouts
between those two trades bringing the right people together at that right time to solve those problems.
Let me go to the next slide here.
At the end of the day, the owner wanted to see was all of this work working,
so we had to quantify the effort. We tried to quantify cost of time reactions.
Our team worked with the general contractor's estimators to take the class reports and calculate man hours
saved and costs saved by resolving the issues early through VDC rather than encountering those issues in the field,
so really justifying this VDC workflow for future projects.
Here, again, I've mapped what I just went through to the VDC framework. What I'd like you to focus on here,
in this particular example, is that 100 percent of the ICE frame and PPM activities were aligned to that very specific challenge I mentioned at the beginning,
reducing rework in the field. That's the client's objective, it was to reduce rework, which lots of project objectives of clash detection and prefabrication.
To close, I'd like to talk about how VDC has been extended through the project life cycle.
I think it's very easy to focus VDC just on the design and construction phase,
but it is important to understand that this can have a lifecycle for facilities management and operations.
Here's a project we did at a university with a specific focus on building operations.
The challenge presented by the owner was that if facilities management and workflow could
help reduce the project lifecycle costs and streamline facilities management and operations processes.
Here is a snapshot to give you a better idea of what was happening on the project.
We had the project frame that was created throughout the design and construction process,
which we then linked to customized asset data as well as O&M documents,
operating and maintenance documents. We worked with the owner to determine what five attributes are
most important to the facilities management operational processes. That became the Asset IDs or Asset tab, the equipment type,
manufacturing model number, as well as the room location, that locational data was quite important.
Then each piece of equipment was then linked to the O&M manual. It's become a great tool for them,
both from a visual perspective and from a data perspective. If you think through the software workflow,
you see that we had a software that became really that central environment where the building could be
visualized and where the data from the various sources was linked. On the right side of the slide,
you see just that spreadsheet of data. I think when you juxtapose this spreadsheet of data to what I showed before,
you really start to see the value of putting everything in that central location and having a data and visual link.
It became an important tool to make this building information more accessible for any stakeholder involved in operations,
facilities management, or engaged in future construction or renovation efforts.
My slide is not advancing. Can somebody help me advance to the next framework slide?
>> It looks like it doesn't like the video, Danielle.
Oh, there it is. >> Perfect, there we go.
I'd like to leave you with this visual of how we've extended this idea on other projects.
Here you see a virtual walk through of a mechanical room, where now stakeholders from all around the world can get a glimpse into
their projects and be able to pull up important information about their projects.
What we've noticed is that in light of the remote working situation forced by the COVID-19 pandemic,
there's even more value out of these applications. You can imagine how stakeholders from anywhere in the world can now take a glimpse inside that building.
I'd like to end with just recapping that VDC framework really quickly,
if someone can help me get to that next slide.
>> There's too many cooks.
>> I think we can transition to the next example,
Martin, if you'd like to take it away. >> No. I mean, the recap slide is there.
>> I actually can't see it. I think, if we look at the recap slide here, again,
what I'd like to note is how the VDC framework and the activities done through ICE and through PPM
are all done in line with the project and client objectives.
Really highlighting that, from a project level there was already a value, but if we start to extend this value to
the enterprise and being able to take these volumes across multiple projects, you will be able to make the most of it.
With that, I'll turn it back to you. I'm sorry for the technical hick-ups.
>> Thanks, Danielle, for showing the application of VDC really across many phases of projects and the different types of projects.
I want to just conclude very rapidly with a couple more case examples to show you the global reach of VDC,
because we've seen project teams really around the world taking advantage of VDC. Here, Jon Sakarias Liknes from Kruse Smith
led the deployment of VDC for the delivery of a university building in Western Norway.
The client had a simple request, "We want the best teaching building in Western Norway," and nothing more than that.
That included dramatically reduce CO2 emissions, bring maximum rating, that's a zero energy building,
zero mistakes at hand-over, of course, on-time budget, all of those things that are quite typical in terms of client and project objectives.
Here you see the workroom they have where they had the ICE sessions, the collaboration sessions,
where they really focused on making sure everything was as pre-fabricatable as possible,
that the construction was really coordinated with the design sequence, all the technical systems were coordinated,
and that each meeting had very clear agendas, objectives, and specified outcomes, so that the team was effective and successful.
In terms of the application of BIM they used it for looking again at pre-fabrication options,
the areas of management on site, the coordination of technical systems,
4D models to share progress, connected with production quantities to deliver reality check.
They brought the temporary structures in and made sure that they didn't collide and they positioned and tested all the crane locations in BIM.
Then in terms of production management, they really connected.
They brought basically the daily planning, weekly planning, into a digital environment.
They developed software to do so. They connected that with BIM, so that they could really execute day-to-day the ambitious targets they had.
You can see, again, the combination of all the elements of VDC that tracked how they were doing regularly.
Here you see how they tracked their collaboration sessions. You can see that they had a dip,
and then they fixed it, and then eventually they had a big dip, and they said, "Oops, this is no longer working.
We thought we had it, but the data show we don't." Then they were able to have ICE sessions at a high level.
This was done with very simple questions like, "Was the session good?" "Did you have meaningful input?"
Questions like that, which we see quite commonly done to create a rapid feedback loop for the team how things are going.
They were able to reduce the duration by three months, and shortened a few other parts of the project as well,
contributed to the three months, and they were able to take a million of contingency funding out of the project,
which, of course, the CFO was very happy with. You see it here represented all of these points in the VDC framework again.
You see, once again, if you take one of those elements out, it's just not quite so successful.
Finally, very rapidly, even though it deserves a whole presentation on its own, Raul Eyzaguirre from COSAPI let the deployment of VDC to deliver
very successfully the main facilities for the Pan Am Games in Lima, designed and built 97,000 square meters of multi-sports facility 18 months.
Obviously, quite an achievement. This was of course, highly scale, critical, high-quality had to be achieved.
As you follow the games last year, it was very, very successful, thanks in part to this performance from this team.
They again brought the right people together in these ICE sessions,
Integrated Concurrent Engineering sessions. They managed to solve 15 critical issues on average every two-hour sessions,
and they had a few sessions each week for long periods.
Maybe we can see five sessions per week. They typically included 10 team members so that
everybody was on the same page and solved the problems together. In terms of BIM, they solved 4,000 issues
before project management construction so that the construction could run much more smoothly,
and we see again, the involvement of the different participants to give your data and their sense of the scale of it.
In terms of managing the process, one of the key successes here was that they in
the early ICE sessions created how the team is going to work together so that everybody was again on the same page
with the procedures they're going to follow and to establish how they're going to use the common data environment. Again, with a multidisciplinary team of 10 key participants.
Here, you'll see one example of how they measure the progress of BIM and
how it contributed to resolving clashes and create a smooth construction.
They found that it was important to get the client involved to define the common objectives.
A tool to really focus in the first ICE sessions on how to work together on the project.
That also, they learned that those sessions take a lot of effort to plan. If you want to have them run well,
use the Cloud and do not only just map the process, but really use it in a continuous improvement cycle with a Plan Do Study Act approach.
We hope that with these examples, you've seen the breadth of use of VDC around the world,
and also in terms of types of projects and project phases. To recap, VDC is really about the power of "And".
Meaning, the definition of objectives, KPIs, if you like that word,
to be supported by collaboration, integrated concurrent engineering with building informational modeling and
attention to process managing the production of the project. VDC aligns the definition of measurable client and project objectives
with the planning, design, engineering, and management methods that people process technology to achieve these objectives.
Thank you for tuning in, for listening to this introduction of VDC,
and we hope we were able to demystify VDC but also give you some inspiration in terms of how you can bring it to your projects.
>> Thank you so much, Martin and Danielle, that was wonderful. I think that's a perfect segue.
You developed and you've worked with professionals who develop into the educational experience to get people up to speed on VDC.
You've also gone through a lot of really wonderful examples of successful implementations. When you're teaching this or when you're talking with people who are
trying to implement VDC, what do you see? What do you and Danielle see as the major obstacles to successfully implementing VDC?
You talked a lot about engaging with the owners and there's a lot of extra time giving them to meet regularly to develop the VDC plans.
So maybe that's one obstacle. But in general, when you've seen an unsuccessful implementation, what's gone wrong?
>> I'm curious to see what Danielle says. I would say that the biggest challenge we've seen around the world is definition of
measurable project and client objectives to really create a target for the project [inaudible] That,
for some reason, has been quite challenging and of course, we will work through in the program,
how to do so and then how to use them. The other two is that the VDC elements are used in isolation,
there's focus on BIM but not enough attention on process or collaboration, or there's focus on working together but
not quite enough use of the other elements and so on. The power of "And" is not realized.
The third one is that people are working in isolation. They're on their projects, they're trying to do great things,
many things got in the way. What we've seen is by creating a community of
practitioners that want to implement VDC on their projects, the learning gets accelerated very rapidly.
The things that work get shared, the things that don't work get shared. In a way, that's very meaningful to the situation you face at the moment,
and that community has proven to be very helpful in getting you
out of your frustration and isolation that we often see on projects when you try to innovate.
I don't know if, Danielle, you want to add something to this? >> Yeah, I can add a little bit.
I think is complimentary to what you brought up. I don't think there's one implementation challenge that we always see.
It's usually a combination of a few things coming together. I do find that if the project team and the owner can
set a strong vision that really lays the groundwork for success, when that vision is not strong and when people starts to lose sight
of the challenge we're trying to solve for or the goals that we have on that project, it starts to break down very quickly.
All of a sudden, you'd have people that are doing a lot of work or they don't understand what they're working for anymore.
I think that that vision is key. More often than not, I find that there is breakdowns on the people side,
less on the tool side. We know that with the right software, the right hardware,
and some training, we can create the BIM and put some of those tools together.
But it's usually more of the people of process side. So I think that's why understanding that full VDC framework is so
important because you really understand how all those different components come together,
Because if even one of those starts to break down, you end up with implementation challenges.
I think the value of learning from people on projects across the globe is that somebody is probably going through
that same challenge or has gone through that challenge before. So you don't have to just learn from your own mistakes,
you can learn from the mistakes of those that came before you and benefit from that.
>> Could you maybe elaborate a little bit on getting people on board. We've gotten quite a few questions about how do you engage with the owner.
I mean, I'm convinced that VDC is the way to go, but how do you engage with the owners in convincing them to adopt VDC,
especially if there's a new higher cost in terms of time or resources?
>> I think that a problem people typically face when talking to owners is that they very quickly get into the weave.
They get into the, "What are we going to do?" I think when talking to owners and when starting to think about how do you align
VDC with those overall organization objectives in the big picture on the projects,
you need to start wider than that. You need to start with, "Hey, what's the vision? What's the values?"
and maybe never actually talk about how the models are created or what PPM workflows are going to be used at the beginning.
They need to understand that overall value proposition. Then I think when it comes to cost,
because I saw that that was specifically mentioned in one of the questions, there's a big difference between upfront costs and total project costs.
Yes, you might spend more costs right now in the planning phase,
but guaranteed that saves you money. In the examples I've showed, it saves you money in general.
[inaudible] saves you money in rework costs. I think there needs to be a reframing of what that
cost means and that all comes down to metrics. If we can't measure it,
we don't know if it's working or not and we don't know how to make changes.
The metrics part of the VDC framework, I think, is essential here.
>> Picking up on that, one way in which I've seen the project team successfully match everybody else to go along and see the value of VDC,
is by establishing a shared metric that mattered to both. For example, on one project,
a large infrastructural project on the East Coast, the project manager for the consultant, together with the client,
they sat down and they said, "What has messed up your project in the past?"
They shared, over coffee, the challenges that they had faced and they realized that
one common challenge they had was answers to questions from the engineering team by the client. Then they agreed on how long that duration should be.
Now they had a metric they could track and they could then use to adjust the workflows,
adjust the use of tools, adjust the use of timing of bringing people in, etc. That created some of the initial yardstick that mattered to both,
that allow them to then innovate in the context of that project.
Other project teams have created this alignment between the project team and
the owner by really understanding what the client really wants from the facility.
Some clients, for some reason, they are not that open to that, but others actually are once you start asking questions,
and that allowed them to focus not only on the cost, but also on the value of the facility.
That became very important in terms of the focus of the BIM, the people involved in decision-making, etc.
This again started to get the VDC framework going on the project.
It's really through early conversations either creating a bigger picture or vision for the project,
as Danielle also alluded to, or probably both end would be ideal,
and creating a specific metric that you can track frequently that allows you to then bring VDC in.
Those are a couple of successful approaches I've seen.
>> We also gotten a few questions on the spread and the future of VDC.
The first one is, is it spreading to different types? Have you seen implementations in heavy civil constructions such as dams or tunnels?
Similarly, we had a question whether you've seen VDC being brought into manufacturing industries,
whether it might be useful in developing cars or complex manufacturing like airplanes?
>> We've only been seeing it across small, big projects, across infrastructure or industrial,
institutional complex buildings, housing, multifamily residential.
So we have seen it applied in many settings. Because if you think about it,
why would a project be worse if you defined its goals, if you used collaboration,
if you used a good process, if you used good tools? It really, we have seen,
can help you in all types of projects. The interesting question about the application to other sectors, actually,
I usually turn it around because you have probably seen the curve of declining,
of stagnant, construction productivity and the increase in productivity in manufacturing and other industries.
Sometimes we show that. We didn't show it today because we figured that has been shown many times, produced by my colleague,
and he is back here at CIFE initially. Then I was reflecting on why do we see this difference?
Also, I was reflecting because people ask me, "Martin, why are you so convinced that VDC is the right way to do it?"
Basically, manufacturing has increased the value add compared to construction by a factor of two-and-a-half over the last 50 years, at least in the US.
That's in a way bad, in a way a great opportunity for us. But if you reflect what is different
50 years ago in manufacturing and construction and now, 50 years ago in manufacturing,
you didn't see well-defined metrics, objectives. You didn't have lean management processes.
You didn't have attention to process. You didn't have digital tools. You didn't have design for manufacturing.
You didn't have integration of the organization. Today it would be totally unthinkable that
a world leading manufacturing company does so without having a full digital model of what it's building,
without bringing design and manufacturing together, without thinking about the user,
and without having clear objectives, without measuring, adjusting the workflow,
understanding and well-adjusting continuously. You see exactly the VDC elements represented in
the difference in added value per work-hour that has been achieved for the last 50 years in manufacturing.
Then I think we can get to, I'm convinced, by deploying VDC.
